phrases: Act 1: At Journey's End, We Meet
When did you arrive on Luna?
I made a loop around the inner planets.
You arrived just in time to catch the end of Carnival.
My traveling companion, as well as my best friend.
I am pleased to make your acquaintance, Madame.
My... You are the son of General Morcerf.
Is this your first time on Luna?
I suggest you enjoy yourself, then.
This is a city where all your desires can be fulfilled, no matter what they may be.
Apparently, he styles himself a count.
But I am not so sure.
Luna's high society has been abuzz with rumors about him this past month.
There are some who say that he is a nouveau riche who made his fortune on the frontier,
That might be going a little far...
Excuse me, but what is he called?
Death is certain, its hour uncertain.
Are you sure you were not dreaming or something?
This proves that it was real.
I am going to use it to make his acquaintance.
You have no idea who this guy really is.
Begging monsieur's pardon, but are you Viscount Morcerf from room 405?
I have a message from my master, the Count of Monte Cristo.
What do I think of what?
Why would he want to talk to two complete strangers like us?
His note said that he wanted to establish friendly relations...
At least stay and have dinner with the man.
I have some doubts about whether this guy is even a real aristocrat.
He is almost certainly a con-
I am called the Count of Monte Cristo.
Come now, this will not do.
When a man has come all the way to Luna, he simply must try these dishes.
We are the only ones who are eating.
You have not touched anything all through dinner.
Please, you need not concern yourselves about me.
Just as journeys traveled alone are dull, daily meals eaten alone have no flavor.
For me, speaking with guests as I am now is the greatest feast I could wish for.
Incidentally, what did you think of the opera today?
Speaking for myself, I do not normally see operas very often,
So, Monsieur Albert, are you saying that you have someone...
Eugenie and I were chosen for each other by our parents.
I have never been in love like the main character of that opera.
It is the same with everything else in my life.
Something that I can lose myself in.
Something that will grab my heart and never let go.
I set out on this journey to find that something.
Why are you trying to make it sound so noble?
As I recall, the goal of this little quest had more to do with what is below your waist.
Oh, youth is a wonderful thing.
Count, have you ever been in love like that?
What sort of woman was she?
To be honest, I, too, once had feelings for a certain woman.
As well as dreams of a future with this woman.
In short, those dreams were only dreams.
And in those dreams' stead stands the man that I have become.
I thank you for the honor of your company tonight.
I would like you to join me for luncheon on my balcony tomorrow.
We appreciate your kind offer, but we could not possibly accept.
Luna's public executions are the highlight of Carnival.
The festivities reach their peak as the blood of heinous criminals...
One cannot speak of experiencing Luna's Carnival without having seen this spectacle.
Is that not so, Monsieur Albert?
In that case, I shall await you here in this room again tomorrow.
Pleasant dreams to both of you.
You do not look so good.
His hand was as cold as ice...
It was like a corpse's hand...
One is a man who committed murder out of poverty.
One is a man who committed murder over a love affair.
And the third is a man who slaughtered an entire family to steal their possessions.
All three are heinous criminals who are beyond forgiveness.
I did it to feed my family!
My beloved wife and child, please forgive me!
I bet they are just saying anything that might earn them a reprieve.
I am sick of you and your damn whining!
As for me, I killed ten people!
Women and children, I killed'them all!
I want to see some more happy faces out there!
Why do not we have a bit of sport with this?
A sideshow to the execution, as it were.
I have here a single letter.
It is a letter of pardon that was given to me by the Cardinal.
How in the world did you get something like that?
Unfortunately, I have but this one letter of pardon.
To make the choice an impartial one,
Now, please choose one of them.
Come now, it is nothing more than a little game.
If that is the case, should not we hear what they have to say first?!
My good Monsieur Franz, we are not judges.
Regardless of what we do, they are going to die.
I merely suggest that we make use of that fact in order to enjoy ourselves.
At this moment, we have in our hands the power to offer the hand of salvation to them.
Why do you hesitate to make use of that power to do good?
Yes, it almost feels as if one has become God, does it not?
You are using people's lives as a game?!
Our own lives are pieces that are toyed with as part of someone else's game.
Has it ever seemed that way to you?
I was of the opinion that you and I would be friends, Monsieur Albert.
You set out on your journey in order to find something.
To find and grab hold of a new you.
Through the exertion of your own will.
Come on, Albert, let us go!
You will be sorry you did!
A pardon has been issued by the Cardinal!
The condemned man who is to be pardoned is...
Long live His Excellency the Cardinal!
Monsieur Albert, you have done a good deed.
You must not look away, Monsieur Albert.
Hey, let us go to a cafe or something to clear our heads.
Or how about hitting the red-light district?
You hate that sort of thing, do not you?
I guess there is always the casino...
Please, do not talk to me about gambling!
You were the one who was dying to see it in the first place.
And then you let the Count talk you into...
I brought this on my own head, and that is why I am angry!
You are always fussing over me!
I am going back to the hotel to get ready for the ball.
Tonight is the last night of Carnival.
You should not be alone on a night like this.
Today was the worst day of my life.
Hey, do not be in such a rush...
It was a trap set by bandits.
Moment by moment, the hour of death approaches.
Next time on Gankutsuou, The Count of Monte Cristo, act 2:,
Act 2: Until the Sun Rises Over the Moon
Next time on Gankutsuou, The Count of Monte Cristo, act 2:,
Bide your time, and hold out hope!
